required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: CT Assessment of Minimally Invasive Surgery and Computer Assisted Navigation in Total Knee Arthroplasty
clinical_study.official_title: CT Assessment of Minimally Invasive Surgery and Computer Assisted Navigation in Total Knee Arthropla

brief_summary.textblock: The functional flexion axis of the knee can be established by computer-assisted intra-operative data, through range of motion techniques, not specific landmarks such as epicondyles.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Investigator medical practice didn't allow to move forward with the study.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Functional flexion axis of the knee
arm_group.description: The functional flexion axis of the knee can be established by computer-assisted intra-operative data, through range of motion techniques, not specific landmarks such as epicondyles.

intervention.arm_group_label: Functional flexion axis of the knee

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Males and Females over the age of 18 and equal to or less than the age of 60
- Patients scheduled for elective Total knee arthroplasty surgery
- Patients who have signed informed consent and HIPAA Authorization
- Able to speak and understand English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients presenting with evidence of recent trauma, active infection, chronic pain syndrome of the spine, dementia or have been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease
- Pregnant women
- Patients that will not sign the informed consent

reference.citation: Stoeckl B, Nogler M, Krismer M, Beimel C, de la Barrera JL, Kessler O. Reliability of the transepicondylar axis as an anatomical landmark in total knee arthroplasty. J Arthroplasty. 2006 Sep;21(6):878-82.
